question: The frequency band and rate of scan of Airfield Surface Movement radars are:
explanation:
Aerodrome Surface Movement Radars or Indicators (ASMR or ASMI) operate at very short wavelengths of about 3.8cm (SHF).

The beams are narrow with high rotation rates (60 RPM).

On occasions it is possible even to identify aircraft types from the return

More higher frequencies of EHF are rarely used because of scattering and absorption of the signal by moisture and particles in the atmosphere which make them impractical.
subject: Radio Navigation

question: In order to be able to penetrate cloud, a primary radar signal must have?
explanation:
Primary radar systems detect targets by transmitting an electromagnetic wave into the
target area, then detecting the waves that are reflected from the targets. The direction
from which the returning waves approach the radar antenna indicates the bearing of the
target and the time between the transmission of the wave and the arrival of the returning
echo is used to determine the range of the target. This means primary radar is entirely
dependent upon the ability of targets to reflect the electromagnetic waves.

The degree to which electromagnetic waves are reflected by an object is largely
determined by the size of the object relative to the wavelength of the wave. If the object
size is very close to the wavelength this will cause most of the wave energy to be
reflected. This would give very good returns, but would prevent the wave from moving
on to detect more distant objects. So a wavelength close to the size of water droplets in
clouds, would give very good indications of the clouds, but would be unable to penetrate
them. If the object size is much smaller than the wavelength this will permit the wave to
pass the object with very little energy being reflected. This would permit the majority of
the wave to continue to move forward to detect more distance larger objects. So in order
to penetrate cloud, a primary radar signal must have a long wavelength.
subject: Radio Navigation

question: A surveillance radar installation will often consist of?

choices.choice: An SSR and a precision radar.
A primary radar and a VDF.
A primary radar and a secondary surveillance radar (SSR).
A primary radar and a precision radar.

subject: Radio Navigation

question: When flying a Precision Approach Radar in the UK, vertical displacement is based upon:
explanation:
ATC will assume that an aircraft is using QFE on final approach when carrying out a radar approach and any heights passed by the radar controller will be related to the QFE datum. It should be noted that the Obstacle Clearance Height is always given with reference to the aerodrome or threshold elevation.

 

now not being used
subject: Radio Navigation

question: When carrying out a precision radar approach, talkdown normally ceases at _______ nm from touchdown:
explanation: When the pilot has been handed over to the PAR controller and established radio contact, he will be told not to acknowledge any further instructions and to check that his landing gear is down and locked. Thereafter the controller maintains a continuous flow of instructions to the pilot e.g. “You are 3½nm, slightly above the glideslope, increase your rate of descent; turn left 3°, heading 272”. Ranges are usually given every mile until 4nm to go; thereafter at every ½nm. From 2nm ranges are given every ¼nm. The talkdown terminates at ½ nm, or less.
subject: Radio Navigation

question: A ground based radar with a scanner rotation of 60rpm, a beam width in the order of .5° and a PRF of 10000pps would be:

choices.choice: an Airfield Surface Movement Indicator with a theoretical range of 8nm.
an Airfield Surface Movement Indicator with a theoretical range of 16nm.
a high resolution Surveillance Approach Radar.

explanation:
The formula for Rmax is

C / (2 x PRF).

C stands for the speed of light= 300,000,000 m/s

With a PRF of 10000 pulses/s,

the Rmax is = 300,000,000 / 20000 = 15000 m which is equal to 15 km.

Thus the radar can sample up to 15km during each pulse.

15km = 8 nm= Range

 

Aerodrome Surface Movement Radars or Indicators (ASMR or ASMI) operate at very short wavelengths of about 3.8cm (SHF).

The beams are narrow with high rotation rates (60 RPM).
subject: Radio Navigation

the EHF band is not suitable for the provision of the very narrow beams needed for an ASMI radar.
target discrimination using the SHF band is better.

explanation:
Aerodrome Surface Movement Radars or Indicators (ASMR or ASMI) operate at very short wavelengths of about 3.8cm (SHF).

The beams are narrow with high rotation rates (60 RPM).

On occasions it is possible even to identify aircraft types from the return

More higher frequencies of EHF are rarely used because of scattering and absorption of the signal by moisture and particles in the atmosphere which make them impractical.

question: A primary radar has a pulse repetition frequency of 275 pps. The time interval between the leading edges of successive pulses is:
explanation:
Time interval between between leading edges = PRI

PRI= 1/prf

PRF = 275 pps

PRI = 1/275 =0.00364 second = 3.64 milliseconds
subject: Radio Navigation

SHF gives better definition of aircraft type than EHF.

question: A primary radar system has a pulse repetition frequency of 450 pps. Ignoring pulse width and flyback at the CRT, the maximum range of the radar would be:
explanation:
The formula for Rmax is

C / (2 x PRF).

C stands for the speed of light= 300,000,000 m/s

With a PRF of 450 pulses/s,

the Rmax is = 300,000,000 / 900 = 333333 m which is equal to 333km.

Thus the radar can sample up to 333km during each pulse.

333km = 180 nm
subject: Radio Navigation
